metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Explain the formation of a standing wave resulting from the superposition of a travelling wave and its reflection

superposition_principle.name: Superposition Principle
superposition_principle.correct: When waves overlap, their displacements add algebraically at each point. The resultant displacement equals the sum of individual wave displacements.

multiply together.fix: Superposition is addition: if one wave has displacement +2 cm and another +3 cm, the resultant is +5 cm, not 6 cm.
multiply together.action: Practice adding wave displacements at several points along overlapping waves.

average out.fix: We add all displacements, not divide by the number of waves. Two crests meeting doubles the amplitude.
average out.action: Draw two identical waves overlapping and add displacements point by point.

cancel completely.error: Only happens when displacements are equal and opposite.
cancel completely.fix: Complete cancellation requires waves of equal amplitude meeting exactly out of phase. Otherwise, partial cancellation or reinforcement occurs.
cancel completely.action: Consider what happens when a +3 cm crest meets a −2 cm trough.

persistent.gap: You may be confusing superposition with other wave interactions.
persistent.action: Draw several examples of overlapping waves with different amplitudes and phases, calculating resultant displacement at each point.

constructive_interference.name: Constructive Interference
constructive_interference.correct: Constructive interference occurs when waves meet in phase (crest meets crest, trough meets trough), producing a resultant wave with larger amplitude.

waves cancel.error: That describes destructive interference, not constructive.
waves cancel.fix: Constructive means building up. In phase waves reinforce each other, producing larger amplitude.
waves cancel.action: Think of 'construct' as building something bigger.

only at certain frequencies.error: Constructive interference can occur at any frequency.
only at certain frequencies.fix: The type of interference depends on phase relationship, not frequency. Any two waves in phase interfere constructively.
only at certain frequencies.action: Consider two identical waves meeting. If crests align, they reinforce regardless of frequency.

waves combine permanently.fix: Superposition is temporary. When waves separate, each continues with original amplitude and shape.
waves combine permanently.action: Watch wave simulations showing waves passing through each other.

persistent.gap: You may be confusing constructive and destructive interference.
persistent.action: Create a table comparing: constructive (in phase, larger amplitude) vs destructive (out of phase, smaller amplitude).

destructive_interference.name: Destructive Interference
destructive_interference.formula: Waves out of phase → amplitude decreases
destructive_interference.correct: Destructive interference occurs when waves meet out of phase (crest meets trough), producing a resultant wave with smaller amplitude or complete cancellation.

waves are destroyed.error: Energy is conserved. Waves continue after interference.
waves are destroyed.fix: Destructive refers to amplitude reduction at the meeting point, not wave destruction. The waves pass through unchanged.
waves are destroyed.action: The word 'destructive' describes amplitude effect, not wave fate.

only with equal amplitudes.error: Destructive interference occurs whenever out-of-phase waves meet.
only with equal amplitudes.fix: Complete cancellation requires equal amplitudes, but partial destructive interference occurs with unequal amplitudes.
only with equal amplitudes.action: Calculate what happens when a +5 cm crest meets a −3 cm trough.

waves must be identical.error: Any waves meeting out of phase interfere destructively.
waves must be identical.fix: Identical waves are needed for complete cancellation, but any out-of-phase combination reduces amplitude.
waves must be identical.action: Consider waves of different amplitudes meeting 180° out of phase.

persistent.gap: You may not understand how phase determines interference type.
persistent.action: Draw wave diagrams showing crest-meets-trough scenarios with both equal and unequal amplitudes.

wave_reflection_fixed.name: Reflection at Fixed End
wave_reflection_fixed.correct: When a wave reflects from a fixed end, the reflected wave is inverted (undergoes a 180° phase change). A crest reflects as a trough.

no phase change.fix: The fixed boundary cannot move, so the wave must reverse direction and invert to satisfy boundary conditions.
no phase change.action: Think of Newton's third law: the fixed end exerts an opposite force, inverting the pulse.

wave is absorbed.error: Most energy is reflected, not absorbed.
wave is absorbed.fix: A fixed end reflects most wave energy. Some absorption may occur, but reflection dominates.
wave is absorbed.action: Flick a rope tied to a wall and observe the reflected pulse.

amplitude doubles.error: Amplitude changes occur during interference, not reflection itself.
amplitude doubles.fix: The reflected wave has similar amplitude but is inverted. Amplitude changes occur when incident and reflected waves overlap.
amplitude doubles.action: Distinguish between the reflection process and subsequent interference.

persistent.gap: You may be confusing fixed and free end reflections.
persistent.action: Compare: fixed end → 180° phase change (inversion); free end → no phase change. Memorise this distinction.

standing_wave_definition.name: Standing Wave Definition
standing_wave_definition.correct: A standing wave is formed when a travelling wave and its reflection interfere, creating a stationary pattern of oscillation that does not propagate through the medium.

wave that doesn't move.error: The pattern is stationary, but the medium still oscillates.
wave that doesn't move.fix: Standing waves involve oscillation at fixed positions. The wave pattern doesn't travel, but particles move up and down.
wave that doesn't move.action: Watch a standing wave on a string. The string moves, but the pattern stays in place.

single wave at rest.error: Standing waves require two waves travelling in opposite directions.
single wave at rest.fix: A standing wave results from interference of two travelling waves, not a single stationary wave.
single wave at rest.action: You need both incident and reflected waves to form a standing wave.

wave reflecting once.error: Standing waves require continuous reflection, not a single reflection.
wave reflecting once.fix: Standing waves form when continuous waves interfere with their continuous reflections, maintaining a stable pattern.
wave reflecting once.action: Consider a continuous wave source sending waves that continuously reflect and interfere.

persistent.gap: You may not understand how standing waves form from travelling waves.
persistent.action: Trace the process: wave travels → reflects → interferes with incoming wave → creates stationary pattern.

node_definition.name: Node Definition
node_definition.correct: A node is a point on a standing wave where destructive interference causes zero displacement at all times. The medium does not oscillate at nodes.

point of maximum displacement.error: That describes an antinode, not a node.
point of maximum displacement.fix: Nodes have zero displacement always. Antinodes have maximum displacement. Remember: No motion at Nodes.
point of maximum displacement.action: Use the memory aid: Node = No motion.

point where waves cross.error: All points on overlapping waves involve crossing. Nodes are specifically where cancellation occurs.
point where waves cross.fix: Nodes form where crest meets trough consistently, causing permanent destructive interference.
point where waves cross.action: Focus on the interference outcome, not just wave crossing.

point that oscillates slowly.error: Nodes have zero oscillation, not slow oscillation.
point that oscillates slowly.fix: At a node, the two waves always cancel completely. The medium is stationary there.
point that oscillates slowly.action: Between nodes, the medium oscillates. At nodes, it stays at equilibrium.

persistent.gap: You may be confusing nodes and antinodes.
persistent.action: Draw a standing wave and label: nodes at zero displacement, antinodes at maximum displacement.

antinode_definition.name: Antinode Definition
antinode_definition.correct: An antinode is a point on a standing wave where constructive interference causes maximum displacement. The medium oscillates with maximum amplitude at antinodes.

point of zero displacement.error: That describes a node, not an antinode.
point of zero displacement.fix: Antinodes have maximum displacement, nodes have zero. Anti-node means opposite of node.
point of zero displacement.action: Use the memory aid: Antinode = Anti-zero, meaning maximum motion.

always at positive maximum.error: Antinodes oscillate between positive and negative maximum.
always at positive maximum.fix: Antinodes reach maximum positive displacement, pass through zero, reach maximum negative, and repeat.
always at positive maximum.action: Watch an antinode over time. It oscillates like any point on a wave, just with largest amplitude.

where waves travel fastest.error: Standing waves don't travel. Speed is not relevant at antinodes.
where waves travel fastest.fix: Antinodes are positions of maximum oscillation amplitude, not related to wave speed.
where waves travel fastest.action: Focus on displacement amplitude at antinodes, not wave propagation speed.

persistent.gap: You may be confusing amplitude with other wave properties.
persistent.action: At each antinode, measure displacement over time. It oscillates between maximum positive and negative values.

node_antinode_spacing.name: Node-Antinode Spacing
node_antinode_spacing.formula: Spacing = λ/4 (node to antinode), λ/2 (node to node)
node_antinode_spacing.correct: Adjacent nodes are separated by half a wavelength (λ/2). Nodes and antinodes alternate, separated by quarter wavelengths (λ/4).

one wavelength apart.error: Nodes are half a wavelength apart, not one full wavelength.
one wavelength apart.fix: In one wavelength, you pass through two nodes and two antinodes. So node spacing is λ/2.
one wavelength apart.action: Draw a standing wave and count nodes within one wavelength.

spacing depends on amplitude.fix: Node and antinode positions are determined by wavelength, not amplitude. Amplitude affects oscillation size, not position.
spacing depends on amplitude.action: Change the amplitude of a standing wave and observe that node positions don't move.

randomly distributed.error: Nodes and antinodes have fixed, predictable positions.
randomly distributed.fix: The interference pattern is regular. Nodes occur where path difference is (n+½)λ, antinodes where path difference is nλ.
randomly distributed.action: Calculate positions using wavelength and observe the regular pattern.

persistent.gap: You may not understand the relationship between wavelength and node spacing.
persistent.action: Draw standing waves of different wavelengths and measure node spacing in each case.

standing_wave_energy.name: Standing Wave Energy
standing_wave_energy.formula: Energy oscillates between kinetic and potential
standing_wave_energy.correct: In a standing wave, energy is not transmitted along the medium. Energy oscillates between kinetic energy (at equilibrium positions) and potential energy (at maximum displacement).

energy travels along the wave.error: Standing waves do not transmit energy.
energy travels along the wave.fix: Unlike travelling waves, standing waves store energy. The two component waves carry energy in opposite directions, resulting in no net transport.
energy travels along the wave.action: Compare: travelling wave carries energy; standing wave stores energy.

energy is lost at nodes.error: Energy is conserved. It just doesn't pass through nodes.
energy is lost at nodes.fix: Energy is trapped between nodes. At nodes, energy cannot flow, but it oscillates in the regions between nodes.
energy is lost at nodes.action: Think of segments between nodes as independent oscillators storing energy.

maximum energy at nodes.error: Nodes have zero displacement, so zero potential energy when stretched.
maximum energy at nodes.fix: Maximum energy storage occurs at antinodes (maximum displacement). Nodes are energy barriers.
maximum energy at nodes.action: Consider where the medium is most deformed (antinodes) versus at rest (nodes).

persistent.gap: You may be confusing energy in standing and travelling waves.
persistent.action: Compare energy flow: travelling wave = energy propagates; standing wave = energy trapped between nodes.

phase_in_standing_wave.name: Phase in Standing Waves
phase_in_standing_wave.formula: Points between adjacent nodes oscillate in phase
phase_in_standing_wave.correct: All points between two adjacent nodes oscillate in phase with each other. Points on opposite sides of a node oscillate 180° out of phase.

all points in phase.error: Only points between the same pair of nodes are in phase.
all points in phase.fix: A node acts as a phase boundary. Points on one side are in phase with each other but out of phase with points on the other side.
all points in phase.action: Watch a standing wave: segments between nodes move together, but alternate segments move oppositely.

phase varies continuously.error: Phase is uniform within segments, with 180° jumps at nodes.
phase varies continuously.fix: Unlike travelling waves where phase changes continuously along the wave, standing waves have discrete phase regions.
phase varies continuously.action: Mark points in each segment and observe they reach maximum displacement simultaneously.

no phase relationship.error: Standing waves have a well-defined phase structure.
no phase relationship.fix: The phase pattern is regular: in phase within segments, 180° out of phase across nodes.
no phase relationship.action: Identify which points move upward together and which move oppositely.

persistent.gap: You may not understand phase relationships in standing waves.
persistent.action: Colour-code a standing wave diagram: one colour for points that move together, another for points moving oppositely.

travelling_vs_standing.name: Travelling vs Standing Waves
travelling_vs_standing.formula: Travelling: energy propagates. Standing: energy trapped.
travelling_vs_standing.correct: Travelling waves propagate energy through the medium with a moving wave profile. Standing waves have a stationary profile with energy oscillating in place.

standing waves don't involve motion.error: The medium still oscillates in standing waves.
standing waves don't involve motion.fix: In standing waves, the pattern doesn't move but the medium oscillates at each point (except nodes).
standing waves don't involve motion.action: The wave pattern is stationary, but the particles still move up and down.

same wave just viewed differently.error: They are fundamentally different wave phenomena.
same wave just viewed differently.fix: Travelling waves are single waves propagating. Standing waves require two waves interfering.
same wave just viewed differently.action: Count the waves: travelling = one wave moving; standing = two waves interfering.

standing waves have no frequency.error: Standing waves oscillate at a definite frequency.
standing waves have no frequency.fix: Standing waves have the same frequency as the component travelling waves. Each point oscillates at this frequency.
standing waves have no frequency.action: Measure oscillation period at an antinode. It matches the source frequency.

persistent.gap: You may be confusing wave propagation with medium oscillation.
persistent.action: Make a table comparing travelling and standing waves: energy transport, wave profile, particle motion, formation.

standing_wave_conditions.name: Conditions for Standing Waves
standing_wave_conditions.formula: Same frequency, same amplitude, opposite directions
standing_wave_conditions.correct: Standing waves form when two waves of the same frequency and amplitude travel in opposite directions through the same medium.

any two waves.fix: Random wave combinations create complex interference patterns, not stable standing waves. Same frequency is essential.
any two waves.action: Try combining waves of different frequencies. The pattern changes continuously, not standing.

same direction required.error: Waves must travel in opposite directions.
same direction required.fix: One wave travelling forward meets another travelling backward (typically its reflection). This creates the standing pattern.
same direction required.action: A wave meeting its reflection travels opposite to the original. That's what creates standing waves.

only in strings.error: Standing waves occur in many systems.
only in strings.fix: Standing waves form in strings, air columns, electromagnetic cavities, and anywhere waves can reflect and interfere.
only in strings.action: Consider organ pipes (sound), laser cavities (light), and drum membranes (2D standing waves).

persistent.gap: You may not understand the requirements for standing wave formation.
persistent.action: List the three conditions: same frequency, same amplitude, opposite directions. Verify each in examples.
